greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) is the smallest number with exactly n divisors d such that sigma(d)/d is an integer.
comment: a(n) is the smallest number with n multiply-perfect divisors.
Number 1 is only number m such that sigma(d) / d is an integer for all divisors d.
example: a(3) = 84 because 84 with divisors 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 7, 12, 14, 21, 28, 42 and 84 is the smallest number with 3 multiply-perfect divisors (1, 6 and 28): sigma(1)/1 = 1, sigma(6)/6  = 2, sigma(28)/28  = 2.
mathematica: f[n_] := DivisorSum[n, 1 &, Divisible[DivisorSigma[1, #], #] &]; m = 7; s = Table[0, {m}]; c = 0; n = 1; While[c < m, i = f[n]; If[i <= m && s[[i]] == 0, c++; s[[i]] = n]; n++]; s (* _Amiram Eldar_, Oct 25 2020 *)
program: (MAGMA) [Min([m: m in[1..10^5] | #[d: d in Divisors(m) | IsIntegral(&+Divisors(d) / d)] eq n]): n in [1..6]]
(PARI) a(n) = {my(m=1); while (sumdiv(m, d, !(sigma(d)%d)) != n, m++); m;} \\ _Michel Marcus_, Oct 25 2020
results.author: _Jaroslav Krizek_, Oct 24 2020
ext: Name clarified by _Chai Wah Wu_, Nov 01 2020
